My probability is not higher than 98% to account for low-probability but non-zero risks. These include an unexpected and severe technical failure (e.g., a major cyberattack, cascading hardware failure) or a sudden, sharp reversal in policy from a level of government above NOAA, which would be an extraordinary event on such a short timescale. My forecast is not lower because the official, public commitment from the relevant agency is the strongest possible evidence for continuity of service, leaving only low-probability 'black swan' events as paths to a 'No' outcome. I would lower my forecast upon news of a major cyberattack on U.S. government infrastructure or a credible report of a new directive to remove climate data. I would raise it if key officials, such as the Secretary of Commerce, publicly re-affirm the commitment.
